title: BHP puts a Price on transformation
text:
If the newest member of BHP's executive leadership team carried the title "chief improvement officer", he might field fewer inquiries as to what exactly he does every day.

Alas, Jonathan Price carries the burden of expectations that come with an ambitious title like "chief transformation officer", and the task of explaining his role begins in earnest on Wednesday, when he delivers his first major speech in Melbourne.

''When I first contemplated the chief transformation officer role I must

admit that, like many of you, I asked myself 'what’s the job?','' he will say, in a speech titled ''transforming how we transform''.

Price's team of about 200 people are charged with going through every root and branch of the organisation, looking for ways to smooth processes, improve cultures and deliver the incremental gains that can add up to a lot of dollars over time.

It's a broad remit; from helping workers get better results from mechanical equipment they operate, to improving payments systems, reducing safety breaches to even managing the spend of the $US400 million climate investment fund that BHP hopes will reduce its carbon emissions.

While the lofty title might imply that he alone is the guardian of the secret recipe that will deliver BHP to a successful future, Price is adamant that transformation at BHP is going to come from the ground up.
description: Beyond the nebulous title, Jonathan Price's job as chief transformation officer is to deliver improvements across every root and branch of the organisation.
